newsitem.title: RUSSIA: Demand keeps Russia govt paper price at mkt levels.
newsitem.headline: Demand keeps Russia govt paper price at mkt levels.

text.p: The average yield and price at Wednesday's auctions of GKO discount Treasury bills and OFZ interest-bearing bonds was in line with the market level due to heavy demand in the form of non-competitive bids, dealers said.
The average yield on Tuesday was 28.05 percent.
*an additional tranche of 714-day bond (series 24012) at 98.24 pct average price
*total Finance Ministry proceeds were 7.30 trln rbls
*about 7.18 trln rbls in maturing issue of 224-day T-bills (series 23052).

"The Finance Ministry was very wise," a dealer said. "Under conditions of uncertainty on the market, when many Russian operators expect prices to fall it announced an auction of a short-term paper, which is interesting for Russian investors."
The six-month paper on offer today compared with T-bill maturities of around one year at the last few weeks' auctions.
The demand for the T-bill came as a result of a big volume of cheap roubles on the interbank market and a significant Sberbank investment in the maturing issue.
"Everyone knew Sberbank held significant sums in the maturing issue, which it usually re-invests, and that's why they put in non-agressive bids," the dealer said.
IFCI deputy securities department head Andrei Koshchi said there remained about 2.5 trillion roubles for Thursday's trading, which was enough to push up prices.

"There is an opinion that the market is overheated and many Russian participants cut their portfolios waiting for a correction, that's why we should expect growth in both short-term and long-term paper due to continuing non-resident demand," the dealer said.
